title: Notes on Data Science for Social Justice in the Mathematics Community
text: This page contains notes on the paper “Data Science and Social Justice in the Mathematics Community” (Jones et al. 2023). The purpose of these notes is to fill in additional discussion and references not permitted by the constraints of our prospective publication venue.

title: Notes on Data Science for Social Justice in the Mathematics Community
text:
Notes on Section 1




p. 1


QSIDE’s website is https://qsideinstitute.org.




p. 1


See Flores González vs USA , 2022 for another legal brief by PRACDL supported by data analysis.

title: Notes on Data Science for Social Justice in the Mathematics Community
text:
Notes on Section 2




p. 2


Data Science For Social Good’s website is https://www.datascienceforsocialgood.org/.




p. 4


For more on the origins of the slogan “Nothing about us without us,” we refer the reader to Charlton (2000).




p. 4


For more on critical theory, especially in its connection to liberatory pedagogy, see Freire (1996).




p. 4


The disproportionate representation of white men in professional mathematics is highlighted in many places, for example this article.




p. 4


Ho (2011) considers epistemic humility in another relationship involving experts, the relationship between physicians and disabled patients. Epistmic humility is also related to cultural humility, a concept popularized by Tervalon and Murray-Garcia (1998).

title: Contributing
text:
To contribute to this website, you may do one of two things:

The preferred method is to submit a pull request on GitHub:

Navigate to the site’s GitHub repository.
Identify the page on which you would like to contribute. Common choices:

Resources
About
Notes

Edit the content through the GitHub interface.
Submit a pull request with your changes when you are finished.
We will review and deploy your contribution when we can!

(Advanced): you may fork the entire site and submit a pull request. This is the best approach if you have many changes.
If you are not able to submit a pull request on GitHub, you may email Phil Chodrow with the text of your contribution and clear instructions about where modification should be pleased. Please note that this method may result in significantly slower updates.

title: About
text: We published this website to accompany our paper “Data Science and Social Justice in the Mathematics Community,” which is currently a preprint on arXiv.

title: Data Science for Social Justice in the Mathematics Community
